questions.prompt: What defines an approximation in computational methods?
options: Using randomness to estimate a value
Replacing complex quantities with simpler ones while accepting some error
Converting continuous quantities to discrete points
questions.correctAnswer: Replacing complex quantities with simpler ones while accepting some error
questions.explanation: Approximation is about trading accuracy for tractability. You replace something complex (infinite series, detailed physical model) with something simpler (truncated polynomial, ideal model), accepting that the result won't be exact.

questions.prompt: The 3rd-order Taylor approximation of sin(x) is:
questions.explanation: The Taylor series of sin(x) around x = 0 is x − x³/3! + x⁵/5! − ... The 3rd-order approximation keeps terms up to x³: sin(x) ≈ x − x³/6. This is significantly more accurate than the 1st-order (x) for larger values of x.

questions.prompt: Why is the piecewise-linear diode model (Von ≈ 0.7V) an example of approximation?
options: Because it ignores the exponential I-V relationship for a simpler model
Because it linearizes around a bias point
questions.correctAnswer: Because it ignores the exponential I-V relationship for a simpler model
questions.explanation: The piecewise-linear model replaces the actual exponential I-V relationship with two simple rules: I = 0 for V < 0.7V, and I = (V − 0.7)/R for V ≥ 0.7V. This ignores the smooth exponential transition. It's model simplification — discarding physical detail for analytical tractability.

questions.prompt: The Leibniz formula for π converges with error proportional to:
questions.explanation: The Leibniz alternating series π/4 = 1 − 1/3 + 1/5 − 1/7 + ... has error bounded by the first omitted term, which is approximately 1/N after N terms. This is very slow convergence — 1000 terms for 3 correct digits.

options: Yes, linearization is a special case of approximation
No, approximation is a special case of linearization
questions.correctAnswer: Yes, linearization is a special case of approximation
questions.explanation: All linearizations are approximations (you're replacing a nonlinear function with a simpler linear one). But not all approximations are linearizations — truncating a Taylor series to 5th order, rounding a number, or simplifying a model are approximations but not linearizations.

questions.prompt: A bridge designer uses π ≈ 3.14159 while a GPS satellite uses π to 15 digits. Both are using approximation because:
options: They're both truncating an infinite quantity, but with different error tolerances
questions.correctAnswer: They're both truncating an infinite quantity, but with different error tolerances
questions.explanation: π has infinitely many digits. Any finite representation is an approximation. The difference is the error tolerance — a bridge can tolerate 10⁻⁶ relative error, while GPS positioning requires 10⁻¹⁵. Same concept, different acceptable error.

questions.prompt: Why does adding more Taylor series terms NOT always improve accuracy on a computer?
options: Beyond a certain order, the approximation error becomes smaller than floating-point rounding error
questions.correctAnswer: Beyond a certain order, the approximation error becomes smaller than floating-point rounding error
questions.explanation: Computers use finite-precision arithmetic (typically 64-bit doubles with ~16 significant digits). Once the Taylor truncation error drops below ~10⁻¹⁶, adding more terms contributes nothing because the result is limited by floating-point representation error.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT primarily an approximation?
options: Truncating a Fourier series to 10 harmonics
Replacing a transistor with its hybrid-π small-signal model
Sampling an audio signal at 44.1 kHz
questions.correctAnswer: Sampling an audio signal at 44.1 kHz
questions.explanation: Sampling at 44.1 kHz is primarily discretization — converting a continuous-time signal into discrete samples. The other three are approximations: truncating an infinite series, simplifying a device model, and representing an irrational number with a rational one.

questions.prompt: The error in an N-term Taylor approximation of sin(x) around x = 0 is bounded by:
questions.explanation: The Taylor remainder theorem states that the error after N terms is at most |x|^(N+1)/(N+1)! for the sin(x) series. The factorial in the denominator is why higher-order Taylor approximations converge so rapidly — factorial growth dominates polynomial growth.

questions.prompt: When approximating the exact diode equation for forward bias as I ≈ Is·e^(V/Vt), what physical behavior is ignored?
options: The −1 term, which matters only near V = 0
questions.correctAnswer: The −1 term, which matters only near V = 0
questions.explanation: The exact equation is I = Is(e^(V/Vt) − 1). For V >> Vt (about 26 mV at room temperature), e^(V/Vt) >> 1, so the −1 is negligible. Dropping it simplifies the math. But near V = 0, the −1 ensures I = 0 when V = 0, which the approximation gets wrong.
